translated: Points of Controversy
The Great Fifty
The Seventeenth Section
Discussion on the faculties
Is only what is bound to the faculties suffering?
Agreed.

original: Indriyabaddhaññeva aniccaṁ saṅkhataṁ paṭiccasamuppannaṁ khayadhammaṁ vayadhammaṁ virāgadhammaṁ nirodhadhammaṁ vipariṇāmadhammanti?
analyzed: aniccam saṅkhatam paṭicca samuppannam khaya dhammam vaya dhammam virāga dhammam nirodha dhammam vipariṇāma dhammanti
translated: Is only what is bound to the faculties impermanent, conditioned, dependently arisen, subject to destruction, subject to fall, subject to fading away, subject to cessation, subject to change?
You may not say so.

original: nanu anindriyabaddhaṁ aniccaṁ saṅkhataṁ paṭiccasamuppannaṁ khayadhammaṁ vayadhammaṁ virāgadhammaṁ nirodhadhammaṁ vipariṇāmadhammanti?
analyzed: nanu anindriya baddham aniccam saṅkhatam paṭicca samuppannam khaya dhammam vaya dhammam virāga dhammam nirodha dhammam vipariṇāma dhammanti
translated: Isn’t it the case that what is not bound to the faculties is impermanent, conditioned, dependently arisen, subject to destruction, subject to fall, subject to fading away, subject to cessation, subject to change?
Agreed.

original: Hañci anindriyabaddhaṁ aniccaṁ saṅkhataṁ paṭiccasamuppannaṁ khayadhammaṁ vayadhammaṁ virāgadhammaṁ nirodhadhammaṁ vipariṇāmadhammaṁ, no ca vata re vattabbe—
analyzed: hañci anindriya baddham aniccam saṅkhatam paṭicca samuppannam khaya dhammam vaya dhammam virāga dhammam nirodha dhammam vipariṇāma dhamma no ca vata re vattabbe
translated: Well then, since what is not bound to the faculties is impermanent, conditioned, dependently arisen, subject to destruction, subject to fall, subject to fading away, subject to cessation, subject to change, you should not say that
only what is bound to the faculties is suffering.

analyzed: an indriya baddham aniccam saṅkhatam paṭicca samuppannam pe
translated: Is it not the case that what is not bound to the faculties is impermanent, conditioned, dependently arisen, subject to destruction, subject to fall, subject to fading away, subject to cessation, subject to change,

analyzed: vipariṇāma dhamma tat ca na dukkhanti
translated: and that it is not suffering?
Agreed.
“The eye is impermanent, conditioned, dependently originated, subject to destruction, subject to fall, subject to fading away, subject to cessation.🔽

analyzed: vipariṇāma dhamma tat ca na dukkhanti
translated: “Is what is bound to the faculties impermanent, conditioned, dependently arisen, subject to destruction, disappearance, fading away, and cessation, and is that suffering?”

analyzed: na ha ivam vattabbe pe  indriya baddham aniccam saṅkhatam pe
translated: “It is not to be said that it is connected with faculties.”🔽“Is that which is connected with faculties impermanent, conditioned, dependently arisen, subject to destruction, subject to fall, subject to fading away, subject to cessation?” …
“Is what is bound to the faculties impermanent, conditioned, dependently arisen, subject to destruction, disappearance, fading away, and cessation, and is that not suffering?”

analyzed: āmantā  an indriya baddham aniccam saṅkhatam pe
translated: “Yes.”
“Is what is not bound to the faculties impermanent, conditioned, dependently arisen, subject to destruction, disappearance, fading away, and cessation, and is that suffering?”
“No.”🔽“Is what is not bound to the faculties impermanent, conditioned, dependently arisen, subject to destruction, disappearance, fading away, and cessation, and is that not suffering?”🔽“Yes.”
“Is only what is bound to the faculties suffering?”
“Yes.”🔽“Has it not been said by the Blessed One

original: Nanu yadaniccaṁ taṁ dukkhaṁ vuttaṁ bhagavatā—
analyzed: nanu yat aniccam tam dukkham vuttam bhagavatā
translated: who knows and sees, accomplished and fully enlightened,
that what is impermanent is suffering?”

original: Āmantā.🔽Hañci yadaniccaṁ taṁ dukkhaṁ vuttaṁ bhagavatā—
analyzed: āmantā  hañci yat aniccam tam dukkham vuttam bhagavatā
translated: “Yes.”🔽“Then how can you say that only what is bound to the faculties is suffering?”

original: “anindriyabaddhaṁ aniccaṁ”, no ca vata re vattabbe—
analyzed: an indriya baddham anicca no ca vata re vattabbe
translated: “It is not tenable
that only what is bound to the faculties is suffering.”
“Is it not so that
what is impermanent is suffering?”
“Yes.”

original: Yathā indriyabaddhassa dukkhassa pariññāya bhagavati brahmacariyaṁ vussati, evamevaṁ anindriyabaddhassa dukkhassa pariññāya bhagavati brahmacariyaṁ vussatīti?
analyzed: yathā indriya baddhassa dukkhassa pariññāya bhagavati brahmacariyam vussati evam evam an indriya baddhassa dukkhassa pariññāya bhagavati brahmacariyam vussati iti
translated: “Is it that one lives the holy life under the Blessed One for the full understanding of suffering that is not bound up with the faculties?”
“No, friend.”

original: yathā indriyabaddhaṁ dukkhaṁ pariññātaṁ na puna uppajjati, evamevaṁ anindriyabaddhaṁ dukkhaṁ pariññātaṁ na puna uppajjatīti?
analyzed: yathā indriya baddham dukkham pariññātam na puna uppajjati evam evam anindriya baddham dukkham pariññātam na puna uppajjati iti
translated: “Is it that suffering that is not bound up with the faculties, being fully understood, does not arise again?”
“No, friend.”
“Well then, friend, suffering is not bound up with the faculties.”
The Discussion of What is Bound Up with the Faculties is finished.
